My son's eyes were sunken, and I could see it in the way he moved—like he was already tired of the world, because I was too afraid to bring him to the hospital. I told myself that this was a test, one I had to pass to keep them alive. I told myself that the law was a luxury for people with money, and that love had to be enough to justify everything.

I took what I needed from the store. A box of formula, a few cans of food, a bottle of insulin. I didn't run. I didn't scream. I just walked out with my head down, because I had already decided that if someone stopped me, I would do whatever it took to make them understand—plead, bargain, even lie. I would say I was a mother, and I had no other choice.

I justified it by looking at their faces after I got home. The relief in their eyes when they saw the food. The way my daughter's fever broke the next morning, maybe because she finally had something in her belly, maybe because she believed I could fix this. I told myself that if I had done nothing, that would be the real crime. Not stealing. Not breaking the law. But letting them suffer.

I still do. Every day, I tell myself that I would do it again. Because in the end, what is a law compared to a child’s life?
